  techniques_name: glazing (coating process)  throwing (pottery techniques)  underglazing molding (forming)  firing (technique)  porcelain painting (image-making) freehand drawing (technique)  patterning?

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: This is a blue white jarlet and its aesthetic is comprised of three decorative schemes; the top concentric band is made up of patterned flower petals
 the middle register being that of lotus scrolls
 while the bottom has a curvilinear motif. The surface of the jarlet shows signs of wear; there are patches of browning covering its exterior.

  subject_terms_1: lotus (motif)  cultural diffusion? porcelain paintings (visual works)  freehand drawings (drawings)  symbolism  miniature (size attribute)  utilitarian objects exports

  subject_terms_2: Porcelain
 Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties
 1368-1912 Blue and white ware China China painting  Floral decorations  Porcelain
 Vietnamese  Miniature porcelain

  subject_terms_3: visual arts  Decorative arts Ceramics

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: This globular jarlet features three bands of decoration executed in underglaze cobalt blue around its body
 with stylised lotus scrolls occupying the middle register. The development of Vietnamese blue and white ceramics was spurred by the Chinese occupation of north Vietnam from 1407 to 1428 and the decline of Chinese porcelain exports during the fifteenth century.  Vietnamese potters were quick to capitalise on the gap and became prolific producers of blue and white wares
 which they exported to overseas consumers in Indonesia
 Malaysia and the Phillipines. Small ceramic jars or jarlets were a popular commodity among the local communities and were probably used to contain medicines
 oils and even magic potions.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This globular jarlet features three bands of decoration executed in underglaze cobalt blue around its body, with stylised lotus scrolls occupying the middle register. The development of Vietnamese blue and white ceramics was spurred by the Chinese occupation of north Vietnam from 1407 to 1428 and the decline of Chinese porcelain exports during the fifteenth century.  Vietnamese potters were quick to capitalise on the gap and became prolific producers of blue and white wares, which they exported to overseas consumers in Indonesia, Malaysia and the Phillipines. Small ceramic jars or jarlets were a popular commodity among the local communities and were probably used to contain medicines, oils and even magic potions.
